facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 99 of 1954 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 99 of 1954.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated 20th August 1952 of Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 43 of 1952 arising out of Original Suit No. 1262 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated the 20th August, 1952, of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 43 of 1952 arising out of Original Suit No. 1262 of 1949.

facts.text: Appellant passed an order excommunicating Tyebbhai Moosaji Koicha on February 28, 1934.

anchor.surface_text: On February 28,1934, the Appellant who is the religious head of the Dawoodi Bohra Community, passed an order excommunicating one Tyebbhai Moosaji Koicha.

facts.text: Appellant excommunicated Tahirbhai and Hasan Ali on July 17, 1920.

anchor.surface_text: On July 17, 1920, the appellant had excommunicated two persons, Tahirbhai and Hasan Ali,

facts.text: Validity of 1920 excommunication questioned in suit in Court of Subordinate Judge, Barhampur, went to Privy Council.

anchor.surface_text: and the validity of the order was questioned in a suit instituted in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Barhampur. The litigation went up to the Privy Council,

facts.text: Privy Council held appellant had power to excommunicate but only after observing requisite formalities; 1920 order invalid.

anchor.surface_text: which held that the appellant as the religious head had the power to excommunicate a member of the companymunity, but that that power companyld only be exercised after observing the requisite formalities, and as in that case that had number been done, the order of excommunication was invalid.

facts.text: Appellant passed another order of excommunication on April 28, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Apprehending that the order dated February 28, 1934, was open to challenge under the decision in Hasan Ali v. Mansoorali supra on the ground that it had number companyplied with the requisite formalities, the appellant started fresh proceedings, and on April 28, 1948, passed another order of excommunication.

facts.text: Tyebbhai Moosaji filed suit for declaration that excommunication orders of 1934 and 1948 were invalid.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, Tyebbhai Moosaji filed the present suit for a declaration that both the orders of excommunication dated February 28, 1934, and April 28, 1948, were invalid and for other companysequential reliefs.

facts.text: Original Suit No. 1262 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Original Suit No. 1262 of 1949.

facts.text: Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act XLII of 1949 passed, came into force on November 1, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: While this action was pending, the Legislature of the Province of Bombay passed the Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act Bombay XLII of 1949 prohibiting excommunication, and that came into force on November 1, 1949.

facts.text: Plaintiff contended that the Act rendered the orders of excommunication illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff companytended that the effect of this legislation was to render the orders of excommunication illegal.

facts.text: Appellant contended Act had no retrospective operation.

anchor.surface_text: The answer of the appellant to this companytention was, firstly, that the Act had numberretrospective operation, and that, in companysequence, the orders passed on February 28, 1934, and April 28, 1948, were valid,

facts.text: Appellant contended Bombay Legislature lacked competence as not covered by List 2 or 3 of Seventh Schedule to GOI Act 1935.

anchor.surface_text: and secondly, that the Act was itself unconstitutional, because the subject matter of the impugned legislation was number companyered by any of the entries in List 2 or 3 of Seventh Schedule to the Government of India Act, 1935,

facts.text: Appellant contended Act violates Arts. 25 and 26 of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: After the companying into force of the Constitution, the companytention was also raised that the right of the defendant to excommunicate members of the company- munity was protected by Arts. 25 and 26 of the Constitution,

facts.text: Issue No. 19: Whether orders of excommunication 1934 and/or 1948 invalid by reason of Bombay Act 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The issues in the action were then settled, and issue No. 19, which was raised with reference to the above companytentions, was as follows Whether the orders of excommunication made in 1934 and or 1948 are invalid by reason of the ... Act of 1949?

facts.text: Issue 19 tried as preliminary issue; State of Bombay impleaded as second defendant.

anchor.surface_text: This was tried as a preliminary issue, and as it raised the question of the vires of a statute, the State of Bombay was impleaded as the second defendant in the suit.

facts.text: Shah J held Act retrospective, within competence, does not offend Arts 25 and 26.

anchor.surface_text: Shah J.who tried this issue, held that the impugned Act was retrospective in its operation, that it was within the companypetence of the Provincial Legislature, and further that it did number offend Arts. 25 and 26 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Bombay HC Bench (Chagla CJ, Bhagwati J) dismissed appeal, held Act operates from date of operation, competent, no infringe Arts 25,26; granted certificate under Arts 132,133.

anchor.surface_text: Against this finding, the present appellant preferred an appeal to a Bench of the Bombay High Court, and that was heard by Chagla C. J. and Bhagwati J. who held that under the Act, excommunication meant the companydition of being expelled, that it was a companytinuous state during which the person excommunicated was deprived of his rights and privileges, and that, therefore, the Act would operate to protect those rights from the date it came into operation. They further held that the Act was within the companypetence of the Legislature, and they also repelled the companytention that it infringed the rights guaranteed under Arts. 25 and 26 of the Constitution. In the result, they companycurred in the decision of Shah J. and dismissed the appeal but granted a certificate to appeal to this Court under Arts. 132 and 133 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Plaintiff died on March 11, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Pending the appeal, the plaintiff died on March 11, 1953,

facts.text: Daughter applied on May 22, 1953 to be substituted; not pressed, dismissed October 5, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: and his daughter applied on May 22, 1953, to be substituted in his place. But eventually she did number press the application, and that was dismissed on October 5, 1953.

facts.text: Supreme Court order dated November 21, 1955 amended cause title by deleting plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: In this Court by an order dated November 21, 1955, the cause title was amended by deleting the name of the plaintiff.

facts.text: Only defendant and State of Bombay before the Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the only parties who are number before the Court are the defendant and the State of Bombay.

facts.text: No decree passed in suit; only finding on preliminary issue.

anchor.surface_text: It should be remembered in this companynection that numberdecree had been passed in the suit. Only a finding has been given on a preliminary point,

facts.text: Suit abated upon death of plaintiff as actio personalis moritur cum persona.

anchor.surface_text: On the principle, actio personalis moritur cum persona when he died the suit should abate. As a matter of fact, his legal representative applied to be brought on record, but the application was number pressed. The result is that the suit has abated.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed as not maintainable under Art 132 and 133.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that this appeal must be dismissed, as number maintainable.

issues.text: Whether the orders of excommunication made in 1934 and or 1948 are invalid by reason of the provisions of the Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act of 1949?

anchor.surface_text: The issues in the action were then settled, and issue No. 19, which was raised with reference to the above contentions, was as follows Whether the orders of excommunication made in 1934 and or 1948 are invalid by reason of the ... Act of 1949?

issues.text: The question is whether in the events which have happened, the appeal can proceed

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the only parties who are now before the Court are the defendant and the State of Bombay. The question is whether in the events which have happened, the appeal can proceed. We are of opinion that it cannot.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. N. C. Chatterjee for the appellant argues that as the State of Bombay had been impleaded as a party, and that as the decision on the question of the vires of the Act had been given in its presence, the appellant is entitled to continue the appeal against the State without reference to the plaintiff and seek the decision of this Court on the validity of the Act

Atiqa Begum and others supra , there was a decree, and the requirements of s. 205 were satisfied. Here, there is only a finding on a preliminary issue, and there is no decree or final order.

issues.text: whether the Explanation to Art. 132 applies such that the finding is a final order

anchor.surface_text: The Explanation to Art. 132 provides that For the purposes of this Article, the expression final order includes an order deciding an issue which, if decided in favour of the appellant, would be sufficient for the final disposal of the case.

arguments.claim: The Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act renders the orders of excommunication of 1934 and 1948 illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff contended that the effect of this legislation was to render the orders of excommunication illegal.

arguments.claim: The Act had no retrospective operation, and therefore the orders of excommunication passed on February 28, 1934, and April 28, 1948, were valid and unaffected by it.

anchor.surface_text: The answer of the appellant to this contention was, firstly, that the Act had no retrospective operation, and that, in consequence, the orders passed on February 28, 1934, and April 28, 1948, were valid,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: panytention was also raised that the right of the

arguments.court_reasoning: Shah J held the Act was retrospective in operation; Bombay HC held it operates from date of coming into force due to continuous nature.

arguments.claim: The Act was unconstitutional because the subject matter was not covered by any entries in List 2 or 3 of the Seventh Schedule to the Government of India Act, 1935, and the Bombay Legislature lacked competence.

anchor.surface_text: and secondly, that the Act was itself unconstitutional, because the subject matter of the impugned legislation was not covered by any of the entries in List 2 or 3 of Seventh Schedule to the Government of India Act, 1935,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: panytention was also raised that the right of the defendant to excommunicate members of the company- munity was protected by Arts. 25 and 26 of the C

arguments.court_reasoning: Shah J held within competence of Provincial Legislature; Bombay HC concurred.

arguments.claim: The right to excommunicate members of the community is protected by Articles 25 and 26 of the Constitution, and the Act is void as infringing them.

anchor.surface_text: After the coming into force of the Constitution, the contention was also raised that the right of the defendant to excommunicate members of the community was protected by Arts. 25 and 26 of the Constitution,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: panytention was also raised that the right of the defendant to excommunicate members of the company- munity was protected by Arts. 25 and 26 of the C

arguments.court_reasoning: Shah J held it did not offend Arts. 25 and 26; Bombay HC repelled the contention.

arguments.claim: The impugned Act was retrospective in its operation, within the competence of the Provincial Legislature, and does not offend Articles 25 and 26 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Shah J.who tried this issue, held that the impugned Act was retrospective in its operation, that it was within the competence of the Provincial Legislature, and further that it did not offend Arts. 25 and 26 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Excommunication means the condition of being expelled, a continuous state depriving rights and privileges, so the Act operates to protect those rights from the date it came into operation; the Act is within legislative competence and does not infringe Articles 25 and 26.

anchor.surface_text: Against this finding, the present appellant preferred an appeal to a Bench of the Bombay High Court, and that was heard by Chagla C. J. and Bhagwati J. who held that under the Act, excommunication meant the condition of being expelled, that it was a continuous state during which the person excommunicated was deprived of his rights and privileges, and that, therefore, the Act would operate to protect those rights from the date it came into operation.

arguments.claim: The suit abated on the death of the plaintiff as it is an action personal to him on the principle actio personalis moritur cum persona.

anchor.surface_text: On the principle, actio personalis moritur cum persona when he died the suit should abate. As a matter of fact, his legal representative applied to be brought on record, but the application was not pressed. The result is that the suit has abated.

arguments.claim: The appellant is entitled to continue the appeal against the State of Bombay on the question of vires of the Act without reference to the plaintiff, as the State was impleaded and decision given in its presence, relying on United Provinces v. Mst. Atiqa Begum.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. N. C. Chatterjee for the appellant argues that as the State of Bombay had been impleaded as a party, and that as the decision on the question of the vires of the Act had been given in its presence, the appellant is entitled to continue the appeal against the State without reference to the plaintiff and seek the decision of this Court on the validity of the Act

court_response_anchor.surface_text: t reference to the plaintiff and seek the decision of this Court on the validity of the Act and relies on the decision of the Federal Court in The Uni

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished Atiqa Begum as there suit abated entirely and no decree passed; appeal is continuation of non-existent suit; also not final order under Art. 132/133.

arguments.claim: There can be no appeal as the suit has abated, since an appeal is only a continuation of the suit.

anchor.surface_text: as an appeal is only a continuation of the suit, and there can be no question of continuing what does not exist.

arguments.claim: The order appealed against is only a finding on a preliminary issue, not a decree or final order, so no appeal lies under Art. 132 or s. 205 GOI Act; distinguishes Atiqa Begum where there was a decree.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the order appealed against is only a decision on one of the issues, and it does not dispose of the suit. In The United Provinces v. Mst. Atiqa Begum and others supra , there was a decree, and the requirements of s. 205 were satisfied. Here, there is only a finding on a preliminary issue, and there is no decree or final order.

arguments.claim: The Explanation to Art. 132 does not apply as even if the Act is held invalid, it would not finally dispose of the suit due to other issues remaining.

anchor.surface_text: The Explanation to Art. 132 provides that For the purposes of this Article, the expression final order includes an order deciding an issue which, if decided in favour of the appellant, would be sufficient for the final disposal of the case. Applying this test, even if we accept the contention of the appellant that the impugned Act is bad, that would not finally dispose of the suit, as there are other issues, which have to be tried.

holdings.text: The suit abated on the death of the plaintiff as it is an action personalis moritur cum persona.

anchor.surface_text: On the principle, actio personalis moritur cum persona when he died the suit should abate. As a matter of fact, his legal representative applied to be brought on record, but the application was number pressed. The result is that the suit has abated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaintiff sought personal declaration of invalid excommunication; legal representative did not press substitution application after death.

holdings.text: No appeal can proceed or continue once the underlying suit has abated, as an appeal is only a continuation of the suit.

anchor.surface_text: Here, the action itself has abated, and there can be no question of an appeal in relation thereto, as an appeal is only a continuation of the suit, and there can be no question of continuing what does not exist.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suit abated entirely; cannot continue non-existent suit via appeal.

holdings.text: United Provinces v. Mst. Atiqa Begum has no application to the present case.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished because in Atiqa Begum there was a decree satisfying s.205 GOI Act requirements; here no decree, only preliminary finding, and suit abated.

holdings.text: The order appealed against is only a decision on one issue, does not dispose of the suit, and is neither a decree nor final order.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the order appealed against is only a decision on one of the issues, and it does not dispose of the suit. In The United Provinces v. Mst. Atiqa Begum and others supra , there was a decree, and the requirements of s. 205 were satisfied. Here, there is only a finding on a preliminary issue, and there is no decree or final order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Only finding on preliminary issue (vires); other issues remain untried; contrasts with Atiqa Begum where decree existed.

holdings.text: The Explanation to Article 132 does not apply as a decision in appellant's favour on the Act's validity would not suffice for final disposal of the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The Explanation to Art. 132 provides that For the purposes of this Article, the expression final order includes an order deciding an issue which, if decided in favour of the appellant, would be sufficient for the final disposal of the case. Applying this test, even if we accept the contention of the appellant that the impugned Act is bad, that would not finally dispose of the suit, as there are other issues, which have to be tried.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Favourable ruling on Act's vires leaves other issues to be tried; not sufficient for final disposal.

holdings.text: The appeal is not maintainable under Articles 132 or 133 notwithstanding the certificate granted.

anchor.surface_text: We are clearly of opinion that the appeal is not competent under Art. 132, and the fact that a certificate has been given does not alter the position. It is said that the certificate is also under Art. 133, but under that article also, an appeal lies Only against judgments, decrees or final orders, and no certificate could be granted in respect of an interlocutory finding. The result is that this appeal must be dismissed, as not maintainable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No judgment, decree or final order; certificate cannot confer jurisdiction where none exists under Arts. 132/133.

holdings.text: This order expresses no opinion on the correctness of the decision under appeal and does not preclude the appellant from claiming rights in appropriate proceedings.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Abundant caution to clarify non-prejudicial effect on merits not decided.

anchor.surface_text: On the principle, actio personalis moritur cum persona when he died the suit should abate. As a matter of fact, his legal representative applied to be brought on record, but the application was number pressed. The result is that the suit has abated.

The result is that this appeal must be dismissed, as number maintainable. We should add by way of abundant caution that as we express numberopinion on the 1013 companyrectness of the decision under appeal, this order will number preclude the appellant from claiming such rights as he may have, in appropriate proceedings which he may take.

edges.explanation: holding that appeal cannot continue due to suit abatement supports non-maintainability of appeal under Articles 132/133

anchor.surface_text: estion of the vires of the Act had been given in its presence, the appellant is entitled to companytinue the appeal against the State without referenc

edges.explanation: holding that appeal cannot proceed addresses the issue whether appeal can proceed

anchor.surface_text: Here, the action itself has abated, and there can be no question of an appeal in relation thereto, as an appeal is only a continuation of the suit, and there can be no question of continuing what does not exist.

The result is that this appeal must be dismissed, as number maintainable. We should add by way of abundant caution that as we express numberopinion on the 1013 companyrectness of the decision under appeal, this order will number preclude the appellant from claiming such rights as he may have, in appropriate proceedings which he may take.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the order appealed against is only a decision on one of the issues, and it does not dispose of the suit. In The United Provinces v. Mst. Atiqa Begum and others supra , there was a decree, and the requirements of s. 205 were satisfied. Here, there is only a finding on a preliminary issue, and there is no decree or final order.

The result is that this appeal must be dismissed, as number maintainable. We should add by way of abundant caution that as we express numberopinion on the 1013 companyrectness of the decision under appeal, this order will number preclude the appellant from claiming such rights as he may have, in appropriate proceedings which he may take.

The Explanation to Art. 132 provides that For the purposes of this Article, the expression final order includes an order deciding an issue which, if decided in favour of the appellant, would be sufficient for the final disposal of the case. Applying this test, even if we accept the contention of the appellant that the impugned Act is bad, that would not finally dispose of the suit, as there are other issues, which have to be tried.

The result is that this appeal must be dismissed, as number maintainable. We should add by way of abundant caution that as we express numberopinion on the 1013 companyrectness of the decision under appeal, this order will number preclude the appellant from claiming such rights as he may have, in appropriate proceedings which he may take.

anchor.surface_text: We are clearly of opinion that the appeal is not competent under Art. 132, and the fact that a certificate has been given does not alter the position. It is said that the certificate is also under Art. 133, but under that article also, an appeal lies Only against judgments, decrees or final orders, and no certificate could be granted in respect of an interlocutory finding. The result is that this appeal must be dismissed, as not maintainable.

The result is that this appeal must be dismissed, as number maintainable. We should add by way of abundant caution that as we express numberopinion on the 1013 companyrectness of the decision under appeal, this order will number preclude the appellant from claiming such rights as he may have, in appropriate proceedings which he may take.
